[32y/o, white female] -- I live with my parents, who have no idea how bad my depression is. They think my room is messy because I'm lazy but in reality I just don't have the strength to clean it. I also suffer with sensory issues which makes cleaning harder. My room isn't even messy anymore; it's filthy.
I mostly struggle with managing my bin, which has resulted in a rat infestation in my room. My parents don't know and I'm scared to tell them in case they get mad. But I don't know how to fix it on my own, especially since I don't do well with things like that.
Unfortunately, I need to get my room clean in a week and I just don't know what to do. I've always struggled with cleaning but my depression has made everything so much harder, so I'm very worried that it won't get done in time. 
Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you

Update: Thank you so much for all of your advice. I’m happy to report that although my room isn’t spotless, it’s clean and liveable. Thank you for all of your advice and kind words
column2:
Hi there, 

First off, I'm really proud of you for reaching out for advice, that's a strong first step. It's clear you're facing a tough situation and it's okay to feel overwhelmed. Please know that you're not alone. 

To deal with the situation, let's start with small, manageable tasks. Here's a step-by-step plan:

1. Start by addressing the critter issue. It's important, for both your physical and mental health, to have a clean and safe environment. Consider reaching out to and hiring a pest control service to help with the rat infestation. This could potentially be resolved quickly and may provide you some instant relief. 

2. Once that's under control, consider focusing on one small area at a time to clean. A corner, a shelf, or something manageable. Remember to take breaks as often as you need to. 

3. If it feels too overwhelming to do this on your own, there's no shame in asking for help. Reach out to a friend, colleague, or anyone you trust. You can even hire a cleaning service if that's an option. 

4. Now, it's understandable that you're worried about communicating with your parents. But consider sharing with them about your challenges. They might not fully understand your depression but explaining the situation might give them a chance to support you.

5. As you continue to navigate through this, consider seeking professional mental health support if you haven't already. Therapy can provide you with coping skills and strategies to manage your depression and sensory issues.  

Remember, change takes time, so don't be hard on yourself. Just keep taking small steps in the right direction. You've got this! 

Wonderful update! That sounds like awesome progress you've made, congratulations!! It's no small feat what you've done, and I hope you feel proud. Remember, it doesn't need to be perfect, progress is what matters! We're all here cheering for you!

Don't forget that it's okay to ask your parents or a professional for help and support. The stigma that's often attached to mental health issues - particularly depression - can make it difficult to admit when we're struggling, but your health and well-being should always be your top priority. 

In terms of practical tips for maintaining a clean space, here are some suggestions:

1. Try to make cleaning a regular routine, perhaps setting aside a small amount of time each day to tidy a specific area. This constant effort will keep the task manageable and less overwhelming.
    
2. Aim for 'good enough'. Your room doesn't need to be perfectly clean, it just needs to be livable. Often, the thought of a perfect result can be paralyzing and it's better to work at a pace that's comfortable for you.

3. Organize your possessions. Consider getting storage bins or shelves where you can easily locate and put things away. This might help in reducing the sensory overload.

4. In case of the rat infestation, it's important to seek professional help. You can search for local pest control services or ask your parents to help you out with this. It’s a serious issue that can't be handled alone.

Remember, you're not alone. There are many who are going through a similar struggle and support is available. Don't hesitate to reach out again if you need more advice or just someone to listen. Best of luck in your journey as you continue to make strides in improving your living situation and mental health.

[32y/o, white female] -- "My dad just died and my mom wants me to hang out with her all the time. I''ve never liked doing casual things with her, and I'm very independent.

I don't know how to tell her to leave me alone. The best relationship we ever had was when I lived in another state. I moved back because of my dad, but now he's gone. 

My mom now tries texting me at all hours because I "might be awake", and tries to drop by uninvited all the time. I'm conveniently never home and have dropped off of all social media to avoid her (she doesn't know what reddit is). 

Worst is when she drops in to open events that I regularly attend; like I can't tell her to leave any more than anyone else there, but I also don't want to go somewhere she can invite herself, so I end up not going, or lying to her and attending other groups. 

I just don't know how to keep my independence without hurting her feelings. I get that she's lonely, but I don't want to be her go-to person. 

Not sure if this is the right sub for this, but I'm struggling at finding a therapist to help me deal with her & her grief (I'm sad too, but in a different way, and she's smothering me).
column2:
I'm really sorry to hear about your situation. Losing your dad is undoubtedly tough, and having to deal with your mom's loneliness on top of that is a real burden. It sounds like you respect and care about your mother, but also highly value your own independence. It's important to remember that despite the circumstances, it's still okay to prioritize your own wellbeing. 

You might consider setting boundaries with your mom. This could start with a conversation where you tell her something like, "I love you and I care about you, but I also need to honor my own needs during this time. I'm not always available to provide company, or maybe I just need some personal space to process and heal in the way that makes sense for me." 

Communication could be key here. You could ask her to limit her check-ins to once a day, or request that she doesn't drop by uninvited. If the conversations feel hard to manage, you might consider involving a mediator, like a family therapist if possible, because they can be really helpful during times of transition and conflict.

Remember, it's okay to say no, it's okay to require space, and it's okay to prioritize your own mental health. You are important.

Lastly, for finding a therapist, websites like Psychology Today and Good Therapy should have available therapists listed in your area. They often provide information about each therapist’s specialties, which can be helpful in finding someone who suits your needs. It can be a process, but don’t give up. You deserve to find the right support for your situation.

Stay strong, and take good care of yourself.

Furthermore, have you considered encouraging your mom to seek support outside of you? This could be in the form of counseling, support groups for grieving individuals, or just by hanging out with her friends. This would allow her to express her feelings without relying solely on you, thus offering you some respite. 

Regarding therapy for you, it can be a struggle to find the right person. Consider teletherapy if it's available and accessible; it might widen the net of professionals you could work with. Look for someone who specializes in grief counseling or familial relationships, they might be better equipped to help you navigate this situation. 

Remember, it's okay to not be okay, and it's okay to take care of yourself first. Sending you virtual strength.

[32y/o, white female] -- "My dad just died and my mom wants me to hang out with her all the time. I''ve never liked doing casual things with her, and I'm very independent.

I don't know how to tell her to leave me alone. The best relationship we ever had was when I lived in another state. I moved back because of my dad, but now he's gone. 

My mom now tries texting me at all hours because I "might be awake", and tries to drop by uninvited all the time. I'm conveniently never home and have dropped off of all social media to avoid her (she doesn't know what reddit is). 

Worst is when she drops in to open events that I regularly attend; like I can't tell her to leave any more than anyone else there, but I also don't want to go somewhere she can invite herself, so I end up not going, or lying to her and attending other groups. 

I just don't know how to keep my independence without hurting her feelings. I get that she's lonely, but I don't want to be her go-to person. 

Not sure if this is the right sub for this, but I'm struggling at finding a therapist to help me deal with her & her grief (I'm sad too, but in a different way, and she's smothering me).
column2:
I'm really sorry to hear about the situation you're facing, it must be incredibly tough. Grieving is a very personal and individual process, and it's important to remember that it's okay to prioritize your mental health and emotional wellbeing. 

You might want to have an open and honest conversation with your mom about your feelings - maybe explain how you need your own space to process what has happened and that you too are grieving in your own way. It might be a difficult conversation, but it could help her understand your needs better.

Remember, setting boundaries is much about self-care as it is about balancing relationships. It's not easy, but it's necessary. 

Have regular conversations, check-in on her but set defined timings for your interactions if that helps. This way you're there for her, but not at the risk of your own mental/emotional health.

Losing a loved one can make us reevaluate existing relationships. If you're still struggling to talk to your mom, it could be really beneficial to get in touch with a grief counselor or therapist. They could provide more insight about how to navigate this situation, and they may even be able to mediate conversation with your mom if you feel it necessary.

Hang in there, you're doing your best.

I have very strong emotions and I don’t really know how to process/handle them. 
Does any one have any tips?
column2:
Hey there,

I'm really sorry to hear that you're struggling with this separation anxiety. Firstly, it's crucial to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way. A lot of people experience this, it's not an uncommon thing. Here are a few steps that might help you regain control over your emotions:

1. Regular Exercise: This helps to regulate your body's hormones. Exercise releases endorphins, which help to combat feelings of overwhelming sadness and anxiety.
2. Mindfulness and meditation: These practices can help you stay present-minded and not worry about what is or isn't happening elsewhere. There're numerous apps, like Headspace or Calm that can lead you through short daily exercises.
3. Journaling: Writing out how you feel each time you experience these strong emotions can give you an outlet for those feelings. Writing can also give you a better understanding of your triggers.
4. Seek Support: Connect with a close friend or family member can help. Reach out when you're feeling anxious. If possible, seeing a therapist could be incredibly beneficial.

Remember it's okay to have these feelings and reaching out for help, just like you're doing now, is a huge step in the right direction. Please take care and be gentle with yourself through this.

column1: [32y/o, white female] -- i’ve been struggling with replying to people on social media, especially people i don’t usually talk to. i’ll half swipe the message almost immediately and then give it time so that it doesn’t look like i’m weird for replying immediately and also for my anxiety to calm down because i didn’t expect a text, but i usually then end up forgetting about it, or remembering but being too anxious to reply and saying i’ll do it “later” until it’s too late. i don’t have this problem when i’m texting people who i talk to daily or i’m close with, just like acquaintances and stuff. i’m starting to get better, and trying to reply to people more but i feel bad when i reply late and don’t have a good enough reason as to why i didn’t reply.
column2:
Hello! I can absolutely empathize with what you're going through right now. Social media interaction has its own unique set of anxieties and it’s completely okay to feel the way you do. It's wonderful that you're making an effort to reply more, but try not to beat yourself up if you're not responding as quickly as you'd like.

You need to remember that everyone interacts with social media at their own pace - there's no hard and fast rule about response times, it is okay to take your time. Additionally, you might want to consider setting specific times during your day for checking and responding to social media messages. This way, you're not on call 24/7 and it can help reduce your anxiety.

Likewise, it may be beneficial to briefly explain to the person you're communicating with that you sometimes need a bit of extra time to respond. Most people are understanding of this and respect your honesty. We all have our own comfort zones and boundaries, and it's important to establish and maintain those for our own mental well-being. Keep working at it at your own pace, there's no rush! You're doing great.

Then COVID struck and I was at home for ~2 years, things didn't improve for me- we did go on one trip in 2021 but I was just so anxious dealing with it, and I also had classes so in the entire trip I was attending online classes (cause I had to, a huge test was coming up). My problem is that I'm anxious before the trip happens and during it I'm completely fine. It's gotten better now tho, but not completely cured. Going alone or with friends seems like a mammoth task. Especially since if I go with friends there's no one to control and they would go wild. I know I need to get over this for the future. Any tips?
column2:
Hi there, it sounds like you're dealing with a lot of anxiety around travelling. It's not uncommon to feel this way, especially after a negative experience or a long period of isolation. It's important to take small steps towards your goals.

Firstly, try to figure out what exactly it is about travelling that makes you anxious. Is it the unfamiliarity, potential negative experiences, or being away from a controlled environment? Understanding the root of your anxiety can help you counteract it logically.

Secondly, start small. Plan short trips to places that are familiar and comfortable to you. As your confidence builds, gradually increase the duration and distance of your trips.

Thirdly, plan for contingencies. This means having a plan B in case something doesn't go as planned. This could provide you with a sense of control and help reduce your overall anxiety.

Lastly, consider seeking professional help to talk through your experiences and feelings. They can provide specific methods and techniques to help manage your anxiety. Remember that it's okay to not be okay, and asking for help is a positive step towards healing.

Often, our minds build up scary scenarios about all the things that could go wrong. Try redirecting your focus to the elements of traveling that you enjoy - maybe it's the scenery, the culture, or the food. Train your mind to expect positive experiences.

I'd also suggest trying mindfulness exercises like deep breathing or meditation to help manage your anxiety levels. This could prove helpful not only before a trip, but also during it! Practicing mindfulness can increase your ability to switch off the ‘anxiety mode’ and help you focus on enjoying the present moment.

Maybe start with smaller trips to places closer to home, gradually building up to longer trips. This might help increase your comfort level with travel. And regarding trips with friends, communication is key. Talk to them about your anxieties and set boundaries that you’re all comfortable with.

Remember that it's absolutely okay to get professional help. A therapist or counselor can work with you on coping strategies and help navigate you through this.

You're on the right path by acknowledging the issue and seeking advice. It's okay to take small steps and don't forget to celebrate your progress!

[32y/o, white female] -- I’m sitting here at the bar I that I recently started to manage…. This was supposed to me an exciting step, a new change for a brighter future.  Every single day is work ya know? My job has crept into every aspect of my life. 

My partner hates my job, I just got it in January and we moved in together in February. Having to be on call for work has made me realize how “on call” I am for everything. They can’t accept the fact that I have to help out this restaurant with any problems they have on any given day. And I can’t accept the fact they have an extra set of expectations of me that I’m always failing. 

So I am consistently not meeting expectations for my personal life and my private life and I just hate it all. IT ALL FEELS LIKE WORK. 

I need help. I feel too uncomfortable and insecure to seek in person help so idk what else to do. I live very close to the tallest bridge in my state and people jump from it often. I just want to be another number for that jump list. I want my family to grieve my death for a couple days then just please forget about me. 

Secretly waiting for my parents to pass away, the I feel like I can actually kill myself without causing too much trauma for them. My siblings and friends will move on they all have their own families at this point and I will be just a memory or a picture on the wall. 

I’m just so tired of every day being work, but it’s not even my jobs fault. It only brought it to my attention.

My partner hates my job, I just got it in January and we moved in together in February. Having to be on call for work has made me realize how “on call” I am for everything. They can’t accept the fact that I have to help out this restaurant with any problems they have on any given day. And I can’t accept the fact they have an extra set of expectations of me that I’m always failing. 

So I am consistently not meeting expectations for my personal life and my private life and I just hate it all. IT ALL FEELS LIKE WORK. 

I need help. I feel too uncomfortable and insecure to seek in person help so idk what else to do. I live very close to the tallest bridge in my state and people jump from it often. I just want to be another number for that jump list. I want my family to grieve my death for a couple days then just please forget about me. 

Secretly waiting for my parents to pass away, the I feel like I can actually kill myself without causing too much trauma for them. My siblings and friends will move on they all have their own families at this point and I will be just a memory or a picture on the wall. 

I’m just so tired of every day being work, but it’s not even my jobs fault. It only brought it to my attention.

[32y/o, white female] -- I have no friends aside from one from primary school who I infrequently catch up with. I really just find most people not to be worth talking to, as I find it hard to connect with many people due to my lack of shared interests and my social anxiety.

However, I often feel lonely and kinda sad especially when I see people who are having a good time with their friends.

I did actually have a weird experience making a friend just recently though, but he's way older than me so it's a bit weird to hang out in person. I noticed he had an interest in something I really liked, and we had this great chat for about 10 minutes. It flowed so smoothly, and it was super passionate. We still message each other every couple of days.

Can anyone else relate to this?
column2:
Hello there,

Thank you for sharing your feelings with us, showing vulnerability isn't always easy. You're definitely not alone in this boat. There are many others who experience difficulty making connections due to various reasons. The important thing is that you're making an effort to change things up and even expanding your usual circle. Age doesn't necessarily matter when it comes to friendships, as long as both individuals respect and enjoy each other's company. 

Perhaps you can explore some hobbies or interests that you are passionate about? It's often easier to build friendships around shared interests. There could be clubs, classes, or events near you that you might like to be part of.

Also, bear in mind that it's okay to have a small circle of friends. The quality of the relationship is what matters, not the quantity. If you feel that you connect more deeply on a personal level with fewer people, that's completely okay!

If you ever feel the loneliness gets unbearable or you're feeling really down, it could be helpful to speak with a counselor or therapist. They could provide strategies to cope with social anxiety, and other feelings you're experiencing. Don't be hesitant to reach out for professional help if you feel you need it.

Keep being open and reaching out - every step is progress!
